Key Arguments: The legislation threatens freedom of expression, which is fundamental to democracy.
Social media acts as a modern town square, essential for open exchange of ideas.
There is a concern that the legislation could lead to government censorship and suppression of dissenting views.
The term 'malformation' is criticized as a way to dismiss inconvenient truths.
Fact-checking has been unreliable, with some censored information later proven true.
The legislation could enable government control similar to a 'Ministry of Truth'.
Existing whistleblower protections are strong, questioning the need for additional powers.
The legislation is seen as part of a global trend towards centralized control and away from democracy.
Notable Quotes: Democracy is based on an exchange of ideas, and social medium is the new town square.
Additional government powers will effectively enable a government of the day to silence any one who has a different view point to the Government.
The proposed changes are being promoted as something to protect the public from hate speech, actually the reverse is true.
